contentrichtext.text: {{multiple issues| {{Original research|date=August 2008}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2010}} }} '''Headlinese''' is an abbreviated writing style used in [[newspaper]] [[headline]]s.<ref>[http://www.wordnik.com/words/headlinese Headlinese] Collated definitions via ''www.wordnik.com''</ref> ==Syntax== Because space is limited, headlines are written in a compressed [[Telegram style|telegraphic style]], using special syntactic conventions: * [[Zero copula|Forms of the verb "to be"]] are omitted. * [[Article (grammar)|Articles]] are usually omitted. * Most verbs are in the [[simple present (English)|simple present]] tense, ''e.g.'' "Governor signs bill". * The future is expressed as "to" followed by a [[verb]], ''e.g.'' "Governor to sign bill". * [[Grammatical conjunction|Conjunctions]] are often replaced by a comma, as in "Bush, Blair laugh off microphone mishap".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/europe/07/18/bush.tape.reaction/index.html|title=Bush, Blair laugh off microphone mishap|publisher=CNN|date=2006-07-21|accessdate=2007-07-17 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070816181203/http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/europe/07/18/bush.tape.reaction/index.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-08-16}}</ref> Headlines are generally [[Sentence (linguistics)|sentence]]s or [[noun phrase]]s. ==Short forms== Individuals are usually named by their last name only, with no [[honorific]]s. Organizations and institutions are often named by [[metonymy]]: "Wall Street" for "the financial industry", "Whitehall" for the UK government administration, "Madrid" for "the government of Spain", the "Davos" for "World Economic Forum", and so on. Headlines use many [[contraction (grammar)|contraction]]s and [[abbreviation]]s: in the USA, for example, ''Pols'' (for "[[politician]]s"), ''Dems'' (for "[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]]"), ''GOP'' (for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], from the nickname "Grand Old Party"), ''Govt'' for [[government]]; in the UK, ''Lib Dems'' (for the [[Liberal Democrats]]), ''[[Tory|Tories]]'' (for the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]). Some periodicals have their own distinctive headline styles, especially ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' and its entertainment-jargon headlines such as "[[Sticks nix hick pix]]". ==Commonly used short words== To save space, headlines often use extremely short words in unusual or idiosyncratic ways: {{colbegin|3}} *''axe'' (eliminate) *''bid'' (attempt) *''chop'' *''confab'' (meeting) *''curb'' *''duo'' *''eye'' (consider) *''fury'' (at least in the UK) *''gal'' *''guy'' *''hike'' (increase) *''hit'' *''hype'' *''ink'' (sign a contract) *''laud'' (praise) *''lull'' *''mar'' *''mull'' (consider) *''nab'' *''nix'' (reject) *''parley'' (meeting) *''pen'' (write) *''pose'' *''probe'' (investigation) *''quiz'' (question, either as a noun or a verb) *''rap'' (criticize) *''revel'' *''rout'' *''see'' (forecast) *''slam'' (heavily criticize) *''stun'' *''temblor'' (earthquake) *''tout'' (endorse) *''vie'' (compete) *''woe'' {{colend}} ==Custom== The vocabulary and grammatical constructs used in headlines have become so culturally ingrained that they are often encountered even where there are no space constraints, for example in [[World Wide Web|internet]] [[news agency|news agencies]]' headlines. ==See also== * [[Headline]] * [[Copy editing]] * [[Corporate jargon]] * [[Crash blossom]], an ambiguous headline * [[Ellipsis]], omission of words ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Further reading=== *Headlinese : on the grammar of English front page headlines, Ingrid Mard, ISBN 91-40-04753-9 (pbk.), Lund studies in English [[Category:Headlines]] [[Category:English language]] [[Category:Copy editing]] [[Category:Forms of English]] [[Category:Newswriting]]
